decision_conditions: The Oak and Hornbeam are both situated within the front garden of 3 Copse Wood Way. They are highly visible to the public highway and nearby dwellings. Along with other nearby trees they help to provide a gradual transition of mature tree cover between the dwellings in Copsewood Way and the nearby Ruislip woods National Nature Reserve (NNR). The trees contribute to local biodiversity, and significantly contribute to the amenity and arboreal / wooded character of the Copsewood Estate Area of Special Local Character. They both have a high amenity value.

The structural engineers report dated March 2021 states "It is not viable to carry out the above remedial measures due to the extent of current damage and restrictions imposed by proximity of trees. In our opinion the building has passed its useful life and should be re-built." No mention of tree removal is made within this report.
A report written by a Mark Reeves (unknown qualification) submitted as part of the application mentions an
The removal of deadwood, dangerous / hanging branches and ivy:  This does not require the formal consent of the Council.

description: To remove One Oak (T1 on application) and One Hornbeam (T2 on application) and replace with two Silver Birch, both within Area 1 on TPO 391
